questions.question_text: A general contractor has a list of contract documents containing critical business data that are stored at a public cloud provider. The organizationâ€™s security analyst recently reviewed some of the storage containers and discovered most of the containers are not encrypted. Which of the following configurations will provide the MOST security to resolve the vulnerability?

choices.B: Implementing AES-256 encryption on the containers
choices.C: Enabling SHA-256 hashing on the containers
choices.D: Implementing the Triple Data Encryption Algorithm at the file level

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://www.jetico.com/blog/5-benefits-using-container-encryption-vs-file-encryption

comments.content: Agree, AES-256 on this one for sure.

discussion.content: I agree with B

choices.A: Message queuing telemetry transport does not support encryption.
choices.E: Multiple devices may interfere with the functions of other IoT devices.
choices.C: The devices may cause a dramatic increase in wireless network traffic.
choices.D: The devices may utilize unsecure network protocols.
choices.B: The devices may have weak or known passwords.
choices.F: The devices are not compatible with TLS 1.2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B D, seem to be the best fit here.
Weak password and unsecure protocol IOT

Selected Answer: BD
BD are correct answers

Selected Answer: DE
IoT devices can communicate and pass data between themselves and other traditional systems like computer servers. machine-to-machine (M2M) communication.

Selected Answer: BD
BD because some android OS devices compatible with TLS

comments.content: Thank you... I was thinking C/D. I figured that people can change passwords. But according to NIST, certain IOT devices passwords cannot be changed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ir/2019/nist.ir.8228.pdf

Selected Answer: BD
I think BD is better than BF
Some Android devices are compatible with TLS 1.2 so this statement is false

Selected Answer: BF
Weak password and the Tls1.2 . I think they are the correct answer.

comments.content: Some, but not all IOT devices support Tls 1.2. D is right, because lack of firmware updates to bring these devices to the most up to date security protocols.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B and D are the most likely reason.
B/D sounds right to me

questions.question_text: Which of the following are reasons why consumer IoT devices should be avoided in an enterprise environment? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer B:
10.20.30.40 and 192.168.1.10 are both private IP addresses, which are used for internal networks. Since both IP's are private addresses, its not really exfiltrating data. Line 2 and 3 is what you want to be looking at. The request is Length 15, but ABCDEFJHIJ is only 10 CHARs in length, but you can see the reply is giving additional information, based on the length. Thats why the answer is B. If the request IP was coming from a publicly routable IP address, then the answer would be C.

comments.content: Nothing related with our case, but thanks.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
the answer is ((((A)))) 
I don't know what's going on with you guys 
check this 
https://www.akamai.com/glossary/what-is-icmp-flood-ddos-attack
the answer is B. Please tell me how you can determine if this information is sensitive? C would not work in this scenario.

I asked ChatGPT what an ICMP tunneling request looks like and this is what it said

Sure, here's an example log of a hypothetical ICMP tunneling echo request and reply:

ICMP Request Log:

Date/Time: 2022-09-01 10:15:20
Source IP: 192.168.1.10
Destination IP: 8.8.8.8
Protocol: ICMP
Type: Echo Request
Data: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ

Selected Answer: C
After considering points of other's comments, I'm still answering C.
Ref: https://blog.apnic.net/2022/03/31/how-to-detect-and-prevent-common-data-exfiltration-attacks/

Not A - no spoofing takes place and actual traffic for source and destination is seen in the capture
Not B - I never encountered information leak from memory making "network" actions. However, as for the output, even on the first line " ICMP ECHO REQUEST", the source already has the data ABCDEFGHIJK, surely this is not a leak from the destination (10.20.30.40)
Not D - not relevant to the output log.

comments.content: Agree. I see another response is stating this is Data Exfil possibly using ICMP Tunneling. However, ICMP tunneling is not commonly used and when it is used, it is deployed using special tools and is not done using the ping command.

discussion.content: After reviewing again, I think answer B is the only one that makes sense. The ICMP response from 10.20.30.40 is corrupted, so it's possible that a memory leak on that host might trigger that.

Selected Answer: B
Only "B. Information is leaking from the memory of host 10.20.30.40" has sense to me, as we dont known if the data is sensitive.

Selected Answer: C
This is most likely data exfiltration using ICMP Tunneling (Google it for a better understanding)

comments.content: A memory leak does not send data externally, so answer B doesn't make sense IMO

choices.D: Host 192.168.1.10 is performing firewall port knocking
choices.C: Sensitive data is being exfiltrated by host 192.168.1.10
choices.B: Information is leaking from the memory of host 10.20.30.40
choices.A: The hosts are part of a reflective denial-of-service attack

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
same question on 322
XSS filters have been removed from browsers since around 2018-2019...

Selected Answer: A
we are almost finished!

Selected Answer: A
duplicate answer of 322

Selected Answer: A
A. Typically this is an issue with the web site/server disabling XSS protection on your browser. If this is the case, you can manually adjust that on your browser. Most browsers have this setting on by default.

Selected Answer: D
Repeated questions as user 2Fish has stated

Selected Answer: D
D. Same question. https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/comptia/view/71122-exam-cs0-002-topic-1-question-268-discussion/
